events.comment: Global variables used while in the deck editor.
When we create our list of cards, we use the Atlas Counter to assign an order to the cards as we go.
Card total for decks, adjust to suit your needs.

sub-events.comment: On start of layout, in addition to creating the fade object, the Deck1 function is called to set up to display the first custom deck.
When we enter the Editor, all of our cards are created to be added to the Card atlas (or total list of cards).
The Custom Deck arrays are arranged in the following format:
Y - 0 = The card order, the card atlas is sorted by card order.
Y- 1 = The cards animation. (Picture)
Y - 2 = Card Type. (1 For a Resource card) (2 For a Creature) (3 For a Targeted spell) (4 For a general spell - not targeting a creature) (5 For a Return card spell).
Y - 3 = Card Cost (how much mana it costs to play).
Y - 4 = Creature Card Ranged Attack Value
Y - 5 = Creature Card Melee Attack value.
Y- 6 = Creature Card Defence value.
Y- 7 = Card Buff 1. The first ability attached to the card.
Y -8 = Card Buff 2.
Y - 9 = Buff 1 modifier. If the card buff was gain life, the modifier would be how much life to gain.
Y - 10 = Buff 2 modifier.
Y - 11 = Card Current. How many of any paticular card you have left. Only used in the editor.
Y - 12 = Card Max. The total amount of X card you have at your disposal when putting a deck together. Only used in the editor.
Setting up the deck list. *** Note the order these cards are created determine the order that the cards are displayed in the editor. Swap them around if you wish to change that order.
Creating the Resource Card(s).
Resource Card - (Cost: 0) (Play a Resource card once per turn to increase your mana to cast spells).
Firstly, we create a new column for the CardAtlas array and set the first value to the 'AtlasCounter' number variable.
Next we assign Y - 1 value to the cards animation name.
Next we assign Y - 2 value to the card type value we want (Resource cards are type 1).
***We dont need to assign values to the Y areas that dont apply to the type of card. So we skip to Y - 10
Next we assign Y - 10 value to the card which keeps track of how many of that card is in a deck.
Next we assign Y - 11 which is the maximum amount of the card available.
Creating the Creature Cards.
Weak Creature - (Cost: 1) (1 Attack - 1 Defence).
This is a basic creature without any special card abilities.
The First action remains the same (creates a new column for the array and sets it to the order number).
Next we assign Y - 1 value to the cards animation name.
Next we assign Y - 2 value to the card type value we want (Creature cards are type 2).
Next we assign Y - 3 value to the cost of the card.
Next we assign Y - 4 value to the cards range attack value.
Next we assign Y - 5 value to the cards melee attack value.
Next we assign Y - 6 value to the cards defence value.
Next we assign Y - 11 value to the card which keeps track of how many of that card is in a deck.
Next we assign Y - 12 which is the maximum amount of the card available.
Gaul Castigator
Weak Wall - (Cost: 1) (0 Attack - 2 Defence) (Walls have no attack value so are just used as blockers)
Common Creature - (Cost : 2) (2 Attack - 2 Defence)
Sturdy Wall - (Cost: 2) (0 Attack - 3 Defence)
Spell Creature - (Cost: 2) (1 Attack - 1 Defence) (When played your opponent loses 2 life)
The first example of a creature card with 1 ability attached.
The First action remains the same (creates a new column for the array and sets it to the order number).
Next we assign Y - 1 value to the cards animation name.
Next we assign Y - 2 value to the card type value we want (Creature cards are type 2).
Next we assign Y - 3 value to the cost of the card.
Next we assign Y - 4 value to the cards attack value.
Next we assign Y - 5 value to the cards defence value.
After we have the basic stats set, next we need to add the card buff or abilty.
To do this we assign a value at Y - 6 to the function name of the ability it has (in this case its ability is "EnemyLoseLife" which means when the card is cast the enemy loses X amount of life).
And we add a value to the buff1 modifer at Y - 8 (in this case it is the X amount of life deducted).
Next we assign Y - 10 value to the card which keeps track of how many of that card is in a deck.
Next we assign Y - 11 which is the maximum amount of the card available.
Resource Giver - (Cost: 2) (1 Attack - 1 Defence) (When played the caster gains 1 to maximum mana)
Squire - (Cost: 2) (1 Attack - 1 Defence) (Draw a card when played)
Haste Creature - (Cost: 2) (2 Attack - 1 Defence) (Haste - can attack the turn it is cast)
The Buff 1 modifier is disabled for the haste ability as it doest require a modifer.
Soldier - (Cost: 3) (3 Attack - 4 Defence)
Fortified Wall - (Cost: 3) (0 Attack - 4 Defence)
Shock Mage - (Cost: 3) (2 Attack - 2 Defence) (When played, deal 1 damage to ALL Creatures)
Bounce Creature - (Cost: 3) (1 Attack - 2 Defence) (When played, return a creature to its owners hand)
Slinging Creature - (Cost: 3) (1 Attack - 1 Defence) (When played deal 2 magic damage to an enemy creature)
Terror Creature - (Cost: 3) (2 Attack - 1 Defence) (When played destroy a target enemy Creature)
Raging Druid - (Cost: 3) (3 Attack - 1 Defence) (Haste) (When played the caster gains 1 additional mana)
The first example of a creature card with 2 abilities attached.
The First action remains the same (creates a new column for the array and sets it to the order number).
Next we assign Y - 1 value to the cards animation name.
Next we assign Y - 2 value to the card type value we want (Creature cards are type 2).
Next we assign Y - 3 value to the cost of the card.
Next we assign Y - 4 value to the cards attack value.
Next we assign Y - 5 value to the cards defence value.
After we have the basic stats set, next we need to add the card buff or abilty.
To do this we assign a value at Y - 6 to the function name of the ability it has (in this case its ability is "Haste" which means when the card can attack the run it comes into play).
We would set Y - 8 to the modifier but haste doesnt require one.
For the second ability, we set the Y - 7 to the function name of the ability it has (in this case its ability is "SelfGainResource" which means when the card is cast you gain X additional max mana).
And we add a value to the buff1 modifer at Y - 9 (in this case it is the X amount of extra resources gathered).
Next we assign Y - 10 value to the card which keeps track of how many of that card is in a deck.
Next we assign Y - 11 which is the maximum amount of the card available.
Big Brute - (Cost: 4) (4 Attack - 5 Defence)
Discard Creature - (Cost: 4) (2 Attack - 4 Defence) (When played your opponent loses a random card from their hand))
FireBreather - (Cost: 5) (3 Attack - 5 Defence)
Strong Healer - (Cost: 5) (2 Attack - 6 Defence) (When played the caster gains 5 life)
Creating Spell Cards
Setting up spell cards is a little bit different to creature cards. We dont need to worry about adding attack and defence values for instance.
Weak Spell - (Cost: 1) (when cast deals 2 damage to the opponent's life points)
This is the first example of a spell card.
The First action remains the same (creates a new column for the array and sets it to the order number).
Next we assign Y - 1 value to the cards animation name.
Next we assign Y - 2 value to the card type value we want (Spell cards range from type 3 to 5).
(Type 3 for cards that target an enemy creature) (Type 4 for cards that target your opponent) (Type 5 for the return creature spell).
Next we assign Y - 3 value to the cost of the card.
We skip Y- 4 and Y-5 which was attack and defence.
Next we assign Y - 6 value to the cards first ability (which in this case is "EnemyLoseLife")
Next we assign Y - 8 value to the abilities modifier (in this case how much life the enemy loses).
Next we assign Y - 10 value to the card which keeps track of how many of that card is in a deck.
Next we assign Y - 11 which is the maximum amount of the card available.
Bounce Spell - (Cost: 2) (returns a Creature to its owners hand)
Mind Damage - (Cost: 2) (when cast, your opponent loses a random card from their hand)
Gain Resource - (Cost: 2) (Add 1 to your maximum mana)
Double Draw - (Cost: 3) (caster draws 2 cards
Destroy - (Cost: 2) (Destroy target enemy Creature)
Creature Spell - (Cost: 3) (when cast deals 4 damage to an enemy creature)
Strip Resource - (Cost: 3) (when cast, your opponent loses 1 Mana point and you gain 1)
This is the first example of a spell card with 2 abilities.
The First action remains the same (creates a new column for the array and sets it to the order number).
Next we assign Y - 1 value to the cards animation name.
Next we assign Y - 2 value to the card type value we want (Spell cards range from type 3 to 5).
(Type 3 for cards that target an enemy creature) (Type 4 for cards that target your opponent) (Type 5 for the return creature spell).
Next we assign Y - 3 value to the cost of the card.
We skip Y- 4 and Y-5 which was attack and defence.
Next we assign Y - 6 value to the cards first ability (which in this case is "StripResource")
Next we assign Y - 8 value to the abilities modifier (in this case how many resources the enemy loses).
Next we assign Y - 7 value to the cards second ability (which in this case is "GainResource")
Next we assign Y - 9 value to the cards second ability modifier (which in this case is the amount of resources we want to gain).
Next we assign Y - 10 value to the card which keeps track of how many of that card is in a deck.
Next we assign Y - 11 which is the maximum amount of the card available.
Resource Destroyer - (Cost: 4) (when cast, reduces your opponents resources by 2)
Gain Life - (Cost: 4) (when cast, gain 8 life points)
All Creature Spell - (Cost: 4) (when cast, deal 3 damage to ALL Creatures)
Life Drain - (Cost: 4) (when cast, your opponent loses 4 life points and you gain 2)
Tidal Wave - (Cost: 5) (when cast, destroys all Creatures on the board)
List of abilities you can assign to spells and creatures.

event-group.description: Use this as a reference when creating cards.
event-group.title: Ability Reference

sub-events.comment: *Here is a list of the card abilites that you can apply to cards you create. These abilities are assigned to a spell or creature cards buff 1, 2 and buff 1 and 2 modifiers.
(In addition to the basic stats: Card attack and Defence).
(You can only attach 1 CreatureAbility only to any creature card. This is because all 3 of the abilities below require a target to be brought up).
"CreatureAbilitySingleDamageSpell" :- Deal 'X' damage to an enemy creature, where 'X' is the buff modifier value.
"CreatureAbilityReturnCreature" :- Return an allied or enemy creature to its owners hand.
"CreatureAbilityDestroyEnemy" :- Destroy an enemy creature when played.
"Haste" :- Creatures with haste can attack the first turn they come into play.
Abilities for Creatures and Spells: -------------------------------------------
"EnemyLoseLife" :- Enemy loses 'X' life, where 'X' is the buff modifier.
"EnemyGainLife" :- Enemy gains 'X' life, where 'X' is the buff modifier.
"SelfLoseLife" :- The caster loses 'X' life, where 'X' is the buff modifier.
"SelfGainLife" :- The caster gains 'X' life, where 'X' is the buff modifier.
"CardGain" :- The caster gains 'X' cards. 'X' is the modifier value.
"EnemyRandomDiscard" :- Your opponent discards 'X' random cards. Set by the modifier.
"SelfGainResource" :- Caster gains X resources, set by the modifier.
"SelfLoseResource" :- Caster loses X resources, set by the modifier.
"EnemyGainResource" :- Opponent gains X resources, set by the modifier.
"EnemyLoseResource" :- Opponent loses X resources, set by the modifier.
"DestroyAllCreatures" :- All creatures on the board are destroyed.
"TargetAllCreatures" :- Applies damage to all creatures on the board, set by the modifier.
"TargetAllEnemies" :- Applies damage to all enemy creatures on the board. Set by the modifier.
(You can only attach 1 Spell-only ability to any spell card. This is because all 3 of the abilities below require a target to be selected when cast).
"SingleDamageSpell" :- Enemy creature recieves 'X' damage, set by the modifier.
"ReturnCreature" :- Return a friendly or enemy creature to its owners hand.
"SpellDestroyEnemy" :- Destroy targeted enemy creature.

event-group.description: Moving cards around, adding them to a custom deck or taking them out of one.
event-group.title: Editor Events

sub-events.comment: Touching a button in the editor. If you click on a button while in the Editor screen you will notice it has an instance variable called function. clicking on a button calls whatever function it has attached.
This is to set the frame temporarily for the highlight.
We want the custom deck number to stay highlighted so pressing a deck number sets them all frame 0 and then chooses the button you pressed and sets it to frame 1.
Below is the different functions that buttons in the editor have.
The clear custom deck function.
If custom deck one is active. Deletes columns one by one.
Sets the customs decks ready value to false which means its not ready to use in battle.
When the count reaches 50 it stops and we save the changes into webstorage.
If custom deck two is active.
If custom deck three is active.
Menu button pressed, return to the title layout.
Head to the battle screen to play the game.
Moves the card atlas (or total list of cards) up and down.
Moves the custom deck area up and down (that is if you so many different cards in the deck you cant quite see them all anymore).
This is for the the deck number buttons
Whenever a deck number is pressed, all other arrays are set to active = 0 (which means when we add a card to the deck it only applies to the active deck number).
When a different deck is selected, it might have different amounts of various cards in it, so we need to reset the card atlas to its default value.
Afterwards we call the deck reset function to display the changes on the interface.
From here we deduct the amount of cards in the deck from the rest card atlas (For the current and maximum card amounts).
Then we call on the ResetCustomDeck function to display the changes to the card thumbs.
This event is used to update the cards that are displayed in the card atlas.
All of the stats for the cards are updated so when you drag them into the custom deck area it is easy to transfer it into the carray.
Keeps the card amounts current
Like the above, the events below set up the custom deck card thumbs.
Firstly, set all card thumb objects to the default animation.
If the custom deck 1 is active.
Sets each card thumb along with how many are in the deck.
If the custom deck 2 is active.
If the custom deck 3 is active.
At the end of the group we again call the resetCards function to update how many of each card are available.
Dragging a card in the editor. when a card is touched, it records all the variables to the editor variables and then creates a new card and sets the variables accordingly.
Also sets the active variable to 1 so it follows the touch or cursor.
Touching and dragging the card thumb.
Whenever a card or cardthumb is set to 1 it follows the cursor or touch.

event-group.title: Moving Cards to and from the Deck

sub-events.comment: Another on end of touch event, this will check whether you are dragging out a card from the deck or putting one into it.
If the card is let go over the custom deck area.
Adding a duplicate card to the custom deck.
Custom deck 1 is active.
Checks that deck already contains at least one of the cards to be added.
Updates we storage as you add or take out cards from a custom deck.
Custom deck 2 is active.
Custom deck 3 is active.
Adding the card to the thumb area if not there already.

event-group.title: Adding A fresh Card to Deck

sub-events.comment: Custom deck 1 is active.
Checks that the deck doesnt already contain the card animation. This is so we can tell whether or not to add a new card thumb, or simply add another number to it.
Updates the webstorage to reflect changes.
Custom deck 2 is active.
Custom deck 3 is active.

At the end of the card touch, checks if any of the custom decks have 50 cards (Set by the DeckMax variable at the top of the page), and if so sets the the ready status to true so they can be selected when the game commences.
If the card is not overlapping the custom deck area then it is just destroyed and no changes are made.
If the cardthumb is let go over the card atlas area.
Removing the card from the deck back to the atlas.
Iff customdeck 1 is active.
If customdeck 2 is active.
If customdeck 3 is active.
Checks if the amount of cards left in the thumb area, if 0 then remove the thumb.
If customdeck 1 is active
If there are no more of a paticular card when you remove it, the column is destroyed.
If customdeck 2 is active
If customdeck 3 is active
At the end of the group if any custom deck is not equal to a full deck then the deck is set to false, meaning it wont be available when the game commences.
If the cardthumb is not overlapping the card atlas area then it is just destroyed.
